Award.AwardTitle: CCAPP Symposium - Unraveling the Nature of the Universe with Current and Future Datasets. Conference to be held at Ohio State University
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide participant support for early career scientists and graduate students to participate in the 2nd CCAPP Symposium "Unraveling the Nature of the Universe with Current and Future Datasets." The Symposium, hosted by the Ohio State University's Center for Cosmology and Astro-Particle Physics (CCAPP), will be held on April 4th - 6th, 2011. The symposium will combine plenary session overview talks on astro-particle physics, cosmology, and space science, with four workshops targeted at in depth discussions of more specialized recent topics.

For Broader Impacts, the symposium has a particular focus on early career scientists, graduate students, and local undergraduate students. In advertising the symposium the organizers have targeted especially women and minority groups. To make the symposium more accessible to the general public they have integrated a public lecture by one of the key-note speakers into the schedule.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2nd Symposium of Ohio State's Center for Cosmology and AstroParticle Physics (CCAPP) titled "Unraveling the Nature of the Universe with Current and Future Datasets" was held during April 4 - 6, 2011 in the Physics Research Building in Columbus Ohio. The Symposium consisted of four workshops that proceeded in parallel and a plenary session with overview talks by keynote speakers. The symposium especially targeted early career scientists to present their results and discuss new ideas.  The symposium was organized by a team of 13 CCAPP postdoctoral fellows and each of the workshop was lead by two or three of them. The format of having four parallel workshops was chosen to create a more interactive environment and more easily stimulate discussions in them. While the workshops had very different topics under the framework of the symposium we brought together groups with different backgrounds who frequently engaged in interdisciplinary interactions during the symposium. Workshop topics were:

  1. Constraining Dark Energy and GR with Large Scale Structure Surveys (Tim Eifler, Peter Melchior, Michael Mortonson)
  2. Prospects for Interdisciplinary Science Onboard the International Space Station ( Michael Stamatikos, Haojing Yan)
  3. Supernovae Physics Potential of Current and Next Generation Neutrino Detectors  (Basudeb Dasgupta, Shunsaku Horiuchi, Carsten Rott)
  4. Fermi and Ground Based Gamma-ray Observations  (Kohta Murase, Jennifer Siegal-Gaskins)

The symposium was attended by 55 participants from 21 universities and national labs. Participants were theorists and experimentalists from the fields of cosmology, applied science, astrophysics, and particle physics. The symposium featured 8 overview talks by keynote speakers and 43 parallel session talks by participants and 1 public lecture. NSF funding provided support to twelve early career scientists (graduate students and postdoctoral fellows) to attend the meeting and to present their results.


Materials from the workshop and talks were archived at:
http://ccapp.osu.edu/workshops/Symposium/2011/workshop.html

Broader Impacts: To connect the general public with participants of the symposium, we organized a public lecture that was extremely well attended. Dr. Julie A. Robinson (NASA) talked about "The Era of International Space Station Research". Her talk was archived at:  http://ccapp.osu.edu/workshops/Symposium/2011/publiclecture.html

The event was also featured in Ohio State's onCampus newspaper:

http://oncampus.osu.edu/2011/04/science-in-space/
